guideline_1.title: One fresh document neutralizes staleness
guideline_1.recommendation: Ensure at least one up-to-date document in every retrieval set. The marginal value of additional fresh documents is negligible (S3 with 2 fresh docs: FA=0.427 vs S5 with 1 fresh doc: FA=0.432). Prioritize breadth of coverage over depth of freshness.

guideline_2.title: Timestamp metadata has no measurable impact
guideline_2.recommendation: Including or omitting document timestamps in retrieval context does not affect model accuracy. Even deliberately misleading timestamps (swapping fresh/stale dates) produce no measurable effect. Models appear to rely on content semantics, not metadata, for temporal reasoning.

guideline_3.title: Prioritize refreshing science and sports content
guideline_3.recommendation: Content refresh resources should be allocated based on domain vulnerability. Highest priority: policy and organizations (largest staleness effect TE>0.12). science_life_physical has highest hallucination rate (HR=0.38) — stale scientific content is most likely to produce fabricated answers. Sports has highest outdated-preference (POS=0.24) — models stubbornly cling to old sports statistics.

guideline_4.title: TS and PO mechanisms drive most staleness failures
guideline_4.recommendation: Two mechanisms account for 92% of the staleness effect: Temporal Sensitivity (TS, 69%) and Preference for Outdated (PO, 24%). For TS-type questions (time-sensitive facts like dates, standings, prices), always retrieve the freshest available document. For PO-type questions (where old answers feel authoritative), consider explicitly flagging content age in system prompts or using recency-weighted retrieval scoring.

guideline_5.title: Freshness effect is a step function at the change boundary
guideline_5.recommendation: Document age within stale or fresh categories barely matters — the critical factor is whether the document was captured before or after the factual change. A 6-month-old fresh document is just as good as a 1-month-old one. Implication: refresh frequency should be event-driven (triggered by known factual changes), not calendar-driven.

high_priority_refresh.condition: TS or PO mechanism, policy/organizations/science domain
high_priority_refresh.action: Refresh immediately upon detecting factual change

medium_priority_refresh.action: Ensure at least 1 fresh document in retrieval set

low_priority.rationale: C mechanism shows smallest staleness effect; products domain has highest base FA

not_needed.rationale: Timestamps have zero measurable impact on model performance
